docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Although Peggy Loonan alerts us to some alarming consequences of the name change to Naral Pro-Choice America (''Don't Compromise on Abortion,'' Op-Ed, Jan. 15), she skips quickly over a key benefit. Hearing the word ''choice,'' many women who probably would never abort a pregnancy themselves recognize the fact that some women must. The word ''choice'' prevents the black-and-white view that ''everyone must do as I would do.''

headline.main: Choices for Women: No Room to Yield

docs.abstract: Toni Hargis letter on 'choice' in abortion debate as meaning women must uphold their own views on abortion while supporting right of others to make their own decisions (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether or not boys are harder to raise, they appear to be harder to deliver, according to a new study that found higher rates of Caesarean sections and other complications when boys were born. The study, released on Saturday in BMJ, the journal of the British Medical Association, was conducted at the National Maternity Hospital in Dublin through a review of the records from about 8,000 births, all of them beginning normally.

docs.lead_paragraph: Safe sex -- the proper and consistent use of condoms to protect against sexually transmitted diseases as well as unwanted pregnancies -- still seems to elude a large percentage of sexually active young adults. A newly published survey of 779 sexually active unmarried women 18 to 24 who were recent condom users revealed that in the previous three months 44 percent had waited too long for the condom to be applied.

headline.main: Fact of Life: Condoms Can Keep Disease at Bay

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on importance of proper and consistent condom use to protect against sexually transmitted diseases and unwanted pregnancies; cites failure of large percentage of sexually active young adults to practice such safe sex; drawing (M)i
docs.snippet: Safe sex -- the proper and consistent use of condoms to protect against sexually transmitted diseases as well as unwanted pregnancies -- still seems to elude a large percentage of sexually active young adults.    A newly published survey of 779...

docs.lead_paragraph: J'Vante Anderson is 16, the age her mother was when she had her first child. Growing up in one of Atlanta's poorest neighborhoods, she has seen the cycle: teenage girl has baby, drops out of school, goes on welfare and raises a child who in turn becomes a teenage mother. ''I want to break that cycle,'' she said, her turtleneck perfectly coordinated with her pink velvet jeans. ''I have a life, and I do plan on living it.'' She does not believe in abortion, so she is choosing abstinence.

headline.main: 30 Years After Abortion Ruling, New Trends but the Old Debate

docs.abstract: Supreme Court decision establishing women's right to abortion is now 30 years old, and debate over it continues even as new trends become evident; rate of abortions has declined to its lowest level since 1974, largely because of steady decrease among teenagers, who are avoiding pregnancy through birth control or abstinence; women seeking abortions today are predominantly poor and use birth control unevenly at best; access to abortion is neither 'on demand,' as opponents call it, nor closed off, as some supporters of abortion rights insist, but varies from state to state, subject to ever-shifting equation of geography, money, politics and personal sympathies; New York Times/CBS News Poll indicates that sentiment has barely budged since 1989, with 40 percent of Americans believing abortion should be legal, 20 percent thinking it should not be and another 40 percent saying it should be legal with stricter limits; intense round of anti-abortion legislation at state and federal levels is expected; photo; graphs (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: From a small television screen in the waiting room of the Midwest Medical Center, Dr. Dennis D. Christensen comes off as a cross between a high school biology teacher and a police officer reading the Miranda warnings for the ten-thousandth time. His eyes never meet the camera as he recites how an abortion is performed, its dangers and the alternatives, like adoption. He offers, as the state requires, that a woman may listen to the heartbeat of her fetus and see it on ultrasound if she likes, that she may withdraw consent up to the moment the abortion is induced, that she has the legal right to continue her pregnancy.
docs.abstract: Dr Dennis D Christensen, who has been performing abortions in Wisconsin since 1973, year Roe v Wade was decided, describes various restrictions state has imposed on abortion over last 30 years and how he and other doctors work around them; performs 3,000 abortions a year at five clinics; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the rising incidence of induced labor misstated the publication date of an article in the journal Obstetrics and Gynecology that cited the trend. It was last year, in July, not this year.
docs.abstract: Correction of Jan 14 article on rising incidence of induced labor
docs.snippet: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the rising incidence of induced labor misstated the publication date of an article in the journal Obstetrics and Gynecology that cited the trend. It was last year, in July, not this year.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE printed advertisement showed water gushing through an opening in a dam. ''It could feel like this again,'' the accompanying text said. Puzzled? You probably wouldn't be if you knew where the ad appeared: in the men's restrooms of 100 or so restaurants in Minneapolis and St. Paul last year. The ads, sponsored by Medtronic, the medical device manufacturer, promoted a minimally invasive procedure that can be administered by a urologist to help relieve urinary discomfort from an enlarged prostate. The company, based in Minneapolis, also ran ads in the women's restrooms at the same restaurants, promoting an implantable device to relieve incontinence. These ads had an empowerment theme: ''Bladder control problems shouldn't control your life. You should.''
docs.abstract: Debate on advisability of current spate of direct-to-consumer medical device advertisements discussed; Medtronic's advertising in public restrooms of devices to control incontinence cited; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pollutants in the air in Upper Manhattan and the South Bronx have been linked to lower birth weights and smaller skulls in African-American babies, according to a long-term study on the unusually high rate of childhood asthma in those areas. In a paper to be published next month in the journal Environmental Health Perspectives, researchers at Columbia University's Mailman School of Public Health found that African-American women exposed to high levels of everyday pollutants in automobile exhaust, cigarette smoke and incinerators in the third trimester of pregnancy tended to have smaller babies with smaller than average skulls.

headline.main: Pollution Linked to Low Birth Weights in African-Americans

docs.abstract: Researchers at Columbia University's Mailman School of Public Health find that pollutants in air in Upper Manhattan and South Bronx are linked to lower birth weights and smaller skulls in black babies, which correspond with poor health and mental problems later in life (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For much of her childhood, Joanne Carpenter had to take care of herself -- she lived in public housing in the Bronx with four siblings, a mother who was addicted to drugs, and a father, she says, who wasn't often around. Then, in 1997, she became pregnant at age 16 and it was no longer enough to be self-sufficient. She quickly went from raising herself to raising a child. She had no high school diploma, and no support network to count on.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Single Mother Sets Goals And Tries to Meet Them

docs.abstract: UJA-Federation of New York, which receives support from New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, helps mother find appropriate housing for herself and her young son; photo (M)
